awd_titl_txt: Workshop-NEON: Integrated Carbon and Water for Ecological and Biogeochemical Synthesis (ICWEBS); Wind River Experimen. Forest, WA; Sept. 2016; Boulder, CO; March, 2017; AGU-2017
awd_abstract_narration:
A synthesis team (Integrated Carbon and Water for Ecological and Biogeochemical Synthesis, ICWEBS) will be established to evaluate and coordinate approaches for making best use of atmospheric data collected by the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON). This will be facilitated by organizing a symposium that will bring together 80-120 experts in the field, followed by workshops.  The symposium will result in a series of recommendations for calibration and processing of data that is collected by NEON, as well as examples of how the NEON data can be integrated with other data sets.  Several tangible outcomes will emerge form the proposed work: 1) video tutorials that will be open to students and early career scientists and made available via the internet, 2) articles that will be published in widely read scientific journals or an edited book.  Through these communications, ideas on how to make best use of atmospheric data collected by NEON will be made available to a wide variety of institutions throughout the United States.  The workshops will provide learning opportunities for early career scientists and graduate students.

The National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) will provide the scientific community data on isotopes of water and carbon dioxide at unprecedented temporal and spatial scales.  This data along with appropriate theoretical frameworks will enable the community to make significant advances in understanding carbon and water exchange between the biosphere and the atmosphere.  A synthesis team (Integrated Carbon and Water for Ecological and Biogeochemical Synthesis, ICWEBS) will be established to evaluate and coordinate approaches for making best use of isotopic data collected by NEON.  The synthesis team will organize a symposium involving 80-120 participants to be held late September 2016 near a NEON core site. This symposium will be followed up with workshops with ca 20 people involved in each. By providing: 1) specific recommendations for calibration and processing approaches for the NEON isotopic data streams, 2) examples of the integration of NEON into models of varying levels of complexity, and by 3) broadening of the awareness and utilization of the isotopic data, the proposed workshops will provide the scientific community with the best approaches and most effective ways of using the isotopic data collected by NEON.  Peer reviewed articles resulting from the workshops will be disseminated widely in journals and/or an edited book.

por.por_cntn:
The emergence of real time isotopic measurements has enabled a renewed effort on deducing several ecosystem quantities otherwise difficult to measure. A synthesis activity found consensus on opportunities to estimate water partitioning within ecosystems using isotopic methods. A series of meetings, culminating in a workshop, focused on both theoretical and technical challenges in deducing water partitioning from measurement systems like that deployed by the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON), and provide guidance to enable NEON primary data streams to be converted into derived products for wider dissemination. The team approach promoted learning and training opportunities for a cohort of graduate students and early career scientists engaged ecosystem science.

It was found that while calibration approaches are critical, recent experience with the existing generation of isotopic instruments have revealed robust approaches to evaluate and correct for drift, instrument biases, and calibration to the international standard scale. Procedures to make the necessary corrections to raw data require some degree of customization for different sites to account for humidity, temperature and other environmental factors, yet they can be standardized. The synthesis team identified three complementary approaches to utilize NEON datasets. In all cases it was found that the lack of continual and systematic observations of isotope ratios of soil moisture is a limiting factor for obtaining the most reliable data products from existing NEON investments. Nonetheless, existing algorithms can be adapted to compute 1) the proportion of evaporation relative to local precipitation can be derived on seasonal time scaled by using isotopic measurements of precipitation, soil water, and water vapor to establish a mass balance, and 2) the transpiration ratio (the proportion of evapotranspiration which is transpiration) can be deduced using techniques that have been employed previously with isotopic ratio measurements of ecosystem water fluxes from profile measurements. Additionally, 3) the synergy between leaf and canopy scale exchanges of water and carbon dioxide can be utilized to constrain stomatal and canopy conductance, which gives rise to a direct estimate of water use efficiency, and in turn can be used to further constrain transpiration and carbon assimilation. With algorithms in place to capture the expert knowledge needed to translate raw isotopic measurements into more broadly relevant ecosystem quantities, the value to the wider community can be maximized.
